title: A city council candidate in Washington state was canvassing for votes. He ended up saving a life
text:
CLOSE

A city council hopeful in Washington state was knocking on doors last weekend, looking to drum up support for his campaign.

He ended up providing emergency first aid to a potential voter.

David Regan heard 90-year-old Bill Davis call for help from inside his home in Vancouver, Washington, while saying goodbye to the man's wife. The two rushed to Davis' side, Regan recalled, and discovered the man had fallen and hit his head.

"I walked into the master bedroom and saw a puddle of blood the size of frisbee," Regan told USA TODAY on Tuesday. "His whole head was covered in blood."

Terrified for the man's life, Regan said he applied pressure to Davis' head with a pad and called 911. The man's wife, Cora Ann Davis, found a first aid kit, and they waited for emergency medical services to arrive about five minutes later, he said.

Doctors later put five staples in Davis' head to treat the gash, said Regan, adding that the man's blood-thinning medication increased the risk of him bleeding out. The owner of a bail bond company, Regan had never encountered such an emergency situation, but said his work training taught him to staunch a wound and frequently change bandages.

Vancouver, Washington EMS loads Bill Davis, 90, into an ambulance Oct. 12 after city council candidate David Regan gave him first aid. Regan was canvassing for votes at Davis's home when he fell and hit his head. (Photo: David Regan)

Bill Davis later credited Regan for his quick action: “That saved my life,” he told KGW-TV.

This is Regan's first time running for office. He said he hasn't heard of other local officials encountering a medical emergency while canvassing for votes.

"It was a divine miracle," Regan said. "The Lord had me at the right place at the right time."
